content.description: Persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, regardless of actual value, due to a perceived need to save them and distress associated with discarding. The accumulation results in congested and cluttered living areas that compromise their intended use. Causes clinically significant distress or impairment and is not attributable to another medical condition or mental disorder.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Persistent difficulty discarding possessions regardless of actual value. B. Perceived need to save items and distress associated with discarding them. C. Accumulation of possessions congests and clutters living areas, compromising their intended use. D. Clinically significant distress or impairment. E. Not attributable to another medical condition. F. Not better explained by symptoms of another mental disorder.
content.prevalence: Estimated 2â€“6% of the population; higher rates in older adults.
content.age_of_onset: Typically emerges in adolescence; severity often increases with age.
content.prognosis: Chronic course; without intervention, symptoms often worsen over time. Early treatment and good insight improve outcomes.

circuitry: Involvement of anterior cingulate cortex and insula in decision-making and emotional attachment to possessions.
Altered activity in prefrontal and orbitofrontal regions related to categorization and valuation.
neurochemistry: Possible serotonergic and dopaminergic system involvement.
Stress reactivity and anxiety circuitry contribute to symptom persistence.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Runs in families; early experiences of deprivation or loss may increase vulnerability.

history_psychosocial: Onset, duration, and course of hoarding behaviors.
Types of items saved, organization systems, and storage locations.
Emotional triggers, decision-making patterns, and associated distress.
Impact on living conditions, safety, and relationships.
medical_assessment: Assess for physical hazards (e.g., fire risk, falls, sanitation issues).
Identify any health complications (e.g., respiratory problems from dust/mold).
risk_stratification: Severe clutter creating fire hazard, blocked exits, or unsanitary conditions.
Assess for self-neglect, malnutrition, or inability to care for dependents/animals.
differential_diagnosis: Neurocognitive disorders (e.g., dementia) with impaired decision-making.
Schizophrenia spectrum disorders with disorganized behavior.
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborate with mental health providers, social services, and public health agencies; involve family or support network when appropriate.

core: Distress or anxiety when attempting to discard
associated_features: Avoidance of visitors due to embarrassment

severity_levels.mild: Some clutter; living areas mostly functional.
severity_levels.moderate: Significant clutter in several areas; mild impairment in daily functioning.
severity_levels.severe: Living areas unusable; marked impairment and safety risks.

biological: Family history of hoarding or OCD
environmental: History of poverty, trauma, or significant loss

impact_on_life.school_work: Missed work due to preoccupation with possessions; difficulty completing tasks on time.
impact_on_life.social: Isolation due to embarrassment about living conditions.
impact_on_life.medical: Injuries from clutter, exposure to allergens, poor hygiene.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specialized for hoarding, focusing on decision-making, organizational skills, and exposure to discarding.
Motivational interviewing to enhance readiness for change.
Skills training for sorting and categorizing possessions.
medications: SSRIs may help with comorbid anxiety or depression; limited evidence for direct effect on hoarding symptoms.
care_coordination: Collaboration with public health, fire department, and social services.

treatment_goals: Reduce clutter to improve safety and functionality.
Improve quality of life and social functioning.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Assuming behavior is just extreme collecting without assessing distress or impairment.
Overlooking hoarding in older adults due to isolation.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling normative sentimental attachment as pathological.
Misinterpreting temporary clutter as chronic hoarding.

insight: Good/fair insight: recognizes behavior is problematic
Poor insight: mostly convinced behavior is not problematic
Absent insight/delusional beliefs: fully convinced hoarding is not a problem
with_excessive_acquisition: If difficulty discarding is accompanied by excessive acquisition of items not needed or for which there is no space.

warning_signs: Isolation and refusal of access to home
self_help_strategies: Start with small, manageable decluttering tasks.
Use a timer for short sorting sessions.
Limit incoming items by avoiding sales or free giveaways.

adolescence: Saving seemingly trivial items; reluctance to discard schoolwork or toys.
adulthood: Increased accumulation; reduced living space functionality.
older_adults: Severe clutter; safety hazards; possible neurocognitive decline.

real_life_examples: A 45-year-old unable to discard old newspapers filling the living room, creating fire hazards.
A retiree whose kitchen counters and stove are unusable due to piles of dishes and clutter.
A college student keeping broken electronics 'for parts' despite limited dorm space.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help when clutter prevents safe use of living areas, creates hazards, or causes distress or social isolation.
